image.altText: a woman with blonde hair looking serious

props.synopsis: Women are the fastest growing cohort of prisoners in the NT. But with domestic violence one of the main drivers of female offending, some experts say many of the women being locked up, shouldn't be behind bars at all.

title.children: 'Well-intentioned' policies landing women in prison 'pressure cooker' of trauma and depression

image.altText: A teenage boy in a white hoodie and black baseball cap

props.synopsis: The prosecution argued the four co-accused had formed a "common purpose" to kill Kingsley Alley in the early hours of October 8, 2022, while the defence accused prosecutors of "cherry-picking" evidence.

title.children: Murder trial of four people accused of killing 18-year-old in Darwin driveway hears closing arguments

image.altText: two chinese men standing next to each other with their faces blurred

props.synopsis: An Indigenous ranger group that rescued four asylum seekers on a remote island off the Northern Territory coast last week is calling for the federal government to guarantee their safety.

title.children: 'He said if he's sent back to China, he'll be killed': Rangers question future of asylum seekers found in remote NT

image.altText: Man holding a long gun in front of pink building.

props.synopsis: The suspect allegedly forced a pub patron to drive him almost 300 kilometres before he was apprehended by police.

title.children: CCTV shows outback pub kidnapping suspect throw pair of firearms down before arrest

image.altText: Generic photo of red vape under white light.

props.synopsis: Even after the federal government introduced world-first anti-vaping laws, there seems to be no shortage of tobacconists selling them.

title.children: 'Tsunami' of vapes on the black market despite Australia's world-first laws

image.altText: The outside of the NAAJA building in Darwin.

props.synopsis: One of Australia's top Aboriginal legal services, NAAJA, has publicly apologised for the unlawful sacking of former chief executive officer Priscilla Atkins.

title.children: Aboriginal legal service NAAJA apologises for 'hurt' caused by unlawful sacking of CEO

image.altText: Anzac Oval

props.synopsis: Alice Springs residents are beginning to doubt a controversial plan to construct an Aboriginal art gallery will go ahead after the Northern Territory government revealed its intention to almost halve the building's size.

title.children: 'Hopeless fiasco' of Alice Springs art gallery plan continues as NT government drastically alters building size

image.altText: Copper wiring bundles into circles

props.synopsis: NT Police say thieves have been targeting telecommunication pits in Alice Springs in recent months, using "large vehicles" to pull out hundreds of metres of copper wire.

title.children: Thieves strip Alice Springs telco pits of 'tens of thousands of dollars' worth of copper wire, disrupting services

image.altText: A woman looks at the camera

props.synopsis: Louise Manning thought she knew how to handle the risks of online scammers — but it took one simple question from someone she thought was her friend to be duped.

title.children: A simple text message is allowing scammers to take control of social media accounts

image.altText: The balls falls out of Pat Cummins' hands as he tries to catch it

props.synopsis: Pat Cummins drops a catch and opts not to review a blatant dismissal as Rishabh Pant launches a counter-attack after lunch on day one of the first Border-Gavaskar Test. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Miraculous team catch lights up first day of Test series as Aussies bowl India out

image.altText: Australian players appeal for the wicket of KL Rahul

props.synopsis: A tough opening session for India was made even worse when opener KL Rahul was controversially given out despite the TV umpire seemingly not having enough replays on hand.

title.children: 'I didn't see enough': Indian opener fumes as TV umpire's controversial overturned call leaves tourists in deep trouble

image.altText: A court sketch of a woman with dark skin in a suit wearing handcuffs.

props.synopsis: A Perth grandmother alleging a romance scammer tricked her into trafficking drugs to Japan tells her criminal trial she did not suspect she was being tricked because she was never asked for money.

title.children: Perth grandmother tells trial she was tricked into carrying suitcase of drugs into Japan

image.altText: Tony wears a dark green cap, red polo and grey hoodie and sits in a chair with his kitchen behind him looking out the window

props.synopsis: Tenants in two capital cities are paying more than 30 per cent of their income, on average, towards their rent — for the first time since the SGS Economics Rental Affordability Index was first published a decade ago.

title.children: Rental affordability worst on record, costing more than 30pc of incomes in Sydney, Perth

image.altText: Mr Adani sits at a desk gesuring with his hands.

props.synopsis: American authorities have charged Indian billionaire Gautam Adani over his role in an alleged multi-billion-dollar scheme of bribery and fraud.

title.children: How Indian billionaire Gautam Adani's alleged bribery scheme took off and unraveled

image.altText: Katy Perry smiles in a crystal stripes and stars bikini top, in a make up look resembling Rosie the Riveter.

props.synopsis: A string of legal action was first launched in June 2009 over a trademark held by Katie Jane Taylor, who uses her birth name to design and sell clothes under the brand Katie Perry.

title.children: Katy Perry defeats Sydney fashion designer in federal court following 13-year-long battle

image.altText: a man in a suit standing, and looking on, surrounded by bright lights

props.synopsis: The former Florida congressman denies allegations of sexual misconduct, but says his nomination was "unfairly becoming a distraction to the critical work of the Trump/Vance transition".

title.children: Donald Trump's choice for US attorney-general, Matt Gaetz, withdraws from consideration

image.altText: Mr Vo wears a black leather jacket and carries a green shopping bag while his wife holds his arm and covers her face.

props.synopsis: A four-wheel drive transformed into a "lethal weapon" when a man who had barely driven before got behind the wheel and crashed into two young boys in Melbourne's west last year.

title.children: 'Shocking error': Unlicensed driver who pinned boy between vehicles sentenced to 10 months in jail

image.altText: A NSW police force badge

props.synopsis: A senior police officer accused of crashing an unmarked car in Sydney's NorthConnex tunnel and leaving the scene to avoid being breath tested has been found guilty of mid-range drink driving.

title.children: High-ranking NSW police officer found guilty of mid-range drink driving after Sydney tunnel crash

image.altText: A machete and a sheath lying on a table.

props.synopsis: A 30-year-old Canberra man has lost a bid for bail, after he was charged with attempted murder in the wake of an alleged machete attack in September.

title.children: Man who allegedly severed victim's fingers in machete attack refused bail in Canberra

image.altText: Antarctica research

props.synopsis: Hundreds of polar researchers issue an emergency statement calling for urgent action to deal with the impacts of climate change in Antarctica.

title.children: Antarctic researchers warn of possible 'catastrophic' sea level rise within our lifetime

image.altText: coffs harbour court house external shot

props.synopsis: The defence lawyer for a man charged with the murder of a toddler on the NSW Mid North Coast in 2022 has argued the 38-year-old's "serious health issues" cannot be treated in jail hospital.

title.children: Man accused of toddler's murder refused bail despite 'multiple health issues'

image.altText: Richard Marles in Question Time

props.synopsis: Despite being deputy prime minister, Richard Marles's profile is much lower than that of Treasurer Jim Chalmers, the candidate considered most likely to succeed Anthony Albanese as Labor's leader.

title.children: Richard Marles plays a dead bat on nuclear as the government rushes to get through late work

image.altText: A close-up of a large, ornate wooden door at the front of Victoria's Parliament house

props.synopsis: The Victorian premier says a Memorandum of Understanding between the government and the Israeli Ministry of Defence signed in December 2022 won't be renewed As the state focuses on other "strategic opportunities".

title.children: Victorian government says agreement with Israel's defence ministry will not be renewed

image.altText: Judge in robes.

props.synopsis: A District Court judge has criticised a lack of government funding for the state's courts and the long waiting times for trials while hearing an accused a man's bail application.

title.children: Judge says NSW trial delays are 'intolerable' as he refuses bail for man who will wait over two years for his day in court

image.altText: Rain at Augathella

props.synopsis: Parts of Queensland have marked the highest single-day November rainfall in more than 20 years, the weather bureau says.

title.children: Parts of Queensland mark highest single-day November rainfall in more than 20 years

image.altText: A grassy field near an airport

props.synopsis: Two people were in the helicopter when it came down this morning. The pilot survived and has been taken to Melbourne for treatment.

title.children: One person confirmed dead, survivor injured after helicopter crash in south-west NSW

image.altText: A crowd of people in red hats

props.synopsis: The family of 19-year-old Isla Bell, who was allegedly killed by a man in Melbourne last month, have joined a march in the heart of the city to demand an end to violence against women.

title.children: Isla Bell's family attend anti-violence march in Melbourne

image.altText: A group of young men in AFL jerseys sit together on steps for a photo

props.synopsis: The 2024 AFL draft has been completed, with all 18 clubs adding to their lists with players they hope will be stars of the future. Here's who your club selected and what it means for your team.

title.children: How did your club fare at the AFL draft? Every team's haul analysed

image.altText: Two men - one in a suit, one in a black t-shirt and pants and a black eye - stand in a dry field with a green urn.

props.synopsis: It may not feature a dance-off to 'Super Freak', but this road trip movie about a dysfunctional family features plenty of sweetness and light.

title.children: Two estranged brothers go on a road trip to scatter their mother's ashes in Strange Creatures

image.altText: Professor Stephen Wilson

props.synopsis: Professor Stephen Wilson told a nuclear committee he had received no funding from coal companies. The committee has written to the Institute of Public Affairs fellow to ask if that's true, which he has affirmed to the ABC.

title.children: Pro-nuclear professor linked to Coalition questioned over possible coal industry funding, which he denies

image.altText: Michelle Ananda-Rajah is sitting down wearing a pale blue blazer and a multi-coloured scarf.

props.synopsis: Labor MP Michelle Ananda-Rajah will attempt to make the switch from the House to the Senate as a Victorian Labor candidate at next year's election.

title.children: With no seat to call home, this Labor MP is eyeing off an 'unlikely' switch to the Senate

image.altText: Woman holds back due to pain

props.synopsis: A former insider calls it the "side hustle" of Australia's superannuation funds – where the handling of thousands of death and disability claims from injured workers and grieving families falls to underpaid, overworked staff away from the main game.

title.children: Super fund 'side hustle' leaves workers waiting on insurance payouts

image.altText: A teenager holding a mobile phone up to hide his face

props.synopsis: Immigration law experts argue the changes could have serious implications for the rights of detainees.

title.children: Mobile phones could be confiscated from immigration detainees under new Home Affairs proposal

image.altText: A school of hundreds of sardines in the ocean.

props.synopsis: A study last year identified a sardine population stretching from NSW's south coast to Tasmania could rival the biggest fishery in Australia — and there's a push to make use of it.

title.children: 'Exceeded our predictions': Potentially one of the largest fisheries in Australia is sitting offshore, untapped
